ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

FOOD HYGIENE EDUCATION PROGRAMME


    1. Mr Eugene Yap Giau Cheng asked the Minister for the Environment, with more people eating out, more tourists and the introduction of full-day schools, what plans his Ministry has to provide greater guidance and more effective education for food

Column: 1014

handlers at hawker centres, restaurants and hotels in order to further improve food quality and hygiene.

     The Senior Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment (Mr Chor Yeok Eng) (for the Minister for the Environment)( In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, last year my Ministry conducted an intensive food hygiene education programme for food handlers in the hawker centres, restaurants, coffee shops, school canteens and other food establishments. We handed

Column: 1015

out educational pamphlets in all four official languages explaining the dos and don'ts of food preparation and storage. Talks were also organized for food handlers in hotel catering schools, restaurants and other food establishments.

    After the educational programme, we observed that the number of food handling offences dropped significantly from an average of 55 a week to less than 20 a week. This showed that our food handlers have been made aware of proper food hygiene practices.

    The Ministry takes a serious view of food handlers who disregard proper food hygiene. Offenders will be prosecuted and they stand the risk of having their licences suspended.

    Last year, we took 5,246 food samples for analysis and prosecuted 552 food handlers for selling contaminated food.

     Mr Eugene Yap Giau Cheng (Mountbatten): Mr Speaker, Sir, can the Senior Parliamentary Secretary explain further? With the introduction of full-day schools and with more tourists coming into Singapore, what plans does his Ministry have to provide greater guidance and more effective education for food handlers at hawker centres, etc. to improve the quality of food sold?

     Mr Chor Yeok Eng( In Mandarin): Sir, I have already answered the question asked by the hon. Member as to what we did last year. If he wants to know about future action to be taken to improve food quality and hygiene in view of full-day schools, the increasing number of tourists and so on, what I can tell him now is that we will take further action to carry out the promotion of food hygiene, among other things. This year we will perhaps organize another educational campaign on hygienic food handling and storage.

     Mr Eugene Yap Giau Cheng: Sir, with the introduction of full-day schools, has the Ministry plans to study the nutritional aspect of food sold in school tuckshops?

     Mr Chor Yeok Eng( In Mandarin): Sir, the Member has asked about the food quality and hygiene in school tuckshops as a result

Column: 1016

of the introduction of full-day schools. We are responsible for the licensing of food handlers in the tuckshops. As regards the management and supervision of such food handlers, that is the responsibility of the School Tuckshop Management Committee. If the School Tuckshop Management Committee feels that the stall holders are not able to maintain proper standards of food quality and hygiene, and complain to us, then we will take the necessary action.

SEWERAGE AT PANDAN ROAD
(Completion date)


    2. Mr Yeo Toon Chia asked the Minister for the Environment when the construction of sewerage lines along Pandan Road will be completed, and when the existing factories along Pandan Road will be able to make use of them.

     The Minister for the Environment (Mr Ong Pang Boon): Mr Speaker, Sir, the sewer line along Pandan Road will be ready for use by the end of next month. Factories along this road can then apply immediately to the Sewerage Department for their internal sewers to be connected to the newly completed sewer line.

Column: 1016

FLOOD ALLEVIATION SCHEMES


    3. Mr Yeo Toon Chia asked the Minister for the Environment (a) whether he will give a list of the flood areas in Singapore; and (b) what measures his Ministry plans to take to alleviate flooding in those areas, especially along roads leading to schools.

     Mr Ong Pang Boon: Mr Speaker, Sir, the flood prone areas in Singapore are in Bukit Timah, Potong Pasir, Jalan Eunos, Farrer Park, Opera Estate, Orchard Road, Bukit Panjang, Thomson Road and parts of Chinatown. When there is heavy rainfall, especially during periods of high tide, roads including roads leading to schools in these areas become impassable to traffic.

    We are now widening and deepening the Stamford Canal, Sungei Kallang, Sungei Pang Sua and Siglap Canal, at a total cost of

Column: 1017

$96 million. When these projects are completed, Orchard Road, Potong Pasir, Bukit Panjang, Frankel Estate, Opera Estate and Jalan Eunos should no longer be frequently flooded. Drainage schemes are being planned to alleviate the flooding in the remaining areas.

    It must, however, be pointed out that the flooding of low-lying areas cannot be entirely alleviated by improved drainage. For example, certain parts of the city, in particular Chinatown, are barely above the high tide levels. The ground level of these areas will have to be raised in conjunction with redevelopment, like Potong Pasir, to solve the problem of flooding.

Column: 1017

DISPLAY OF PRICE TAGS BY HAWKERS


    4. Mr Yeo Toon Chia asked the Minister for the Environment whether his Ministry will consider making it compulsory for all licensed hawkers, especially the cooked food sellers, to display approved price tags, so that his Ministry will be able to monitor closely any unjustified price increases by hawkers thus checking profiteering and curbing inflation.

     Mr Chor Yeok Eng (for the Minister for the Environment)( In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, in the debate on this Ministry's head of expenditure on 18th March, I told this House that, according to the law, hawkers are required to display a price list of the various items of food that they sell at their stall. However, this does not mean that we want to control their prices. It will be difficult for the Government to dictate the prices of cooked food. Singapore practises a free market economy. Our hawkers have to buy their supplies from other traders. Moreover, there are enough hawker centres and food stalls in coffee shops throughout the whole of Singapore to generate a sufficiently healthy competition which will act as a check against unreasonable profiteering. Ultimately, the consumers themselves will be the best check against profiteering. They can find out for

Column: 1018

themselves which stalls are charging reasonable prices, and so refuse to patronize those stalls which charge excessive prices.

     Mr Yeo Toon Chia (Ang Mo Kio)( In Mandarin): Sir, I would like to ask the Senior Parliamentary Secretary this question. Although we are aware that hawkers are required by regulations to display price lists at their stalls, are there any checks made on the price lists? How many times have checks been made after display? Does the Hawker Department know that the prices displayed on the price list could be different from the prices actually charged. We have cases of consumers asking for a bowl of mee at 70 cents, for example, but the hawker refused to sell at 70 cents a bowl, saying that there was no such price.

     Mr Chor Yeok Eng( In Mandarin): Sir, I agree that these cases may have arisen. Generally, when we receive complaints of this nature, action is taken. On the other hand, a different kind of situation can arise - the hawker may charge at the prices displayed but give a lesser quantity of food, leading to an argument between the hawker and the consumer. The hawker might argue that if the customer wants a bowl of mee for 70 cents, then that is the quantity he will get unless he pays for more. From time to time when our staff make their rounds, they do advise the hawkers to adjust the price lists according to the actual prices charged. If they want to sell at higher prices, they must tell the consumers frankly what is the price charged and for what quantity. We are always taking action to remind and advise the stallholders about such matters.

Column: 1018

MINISTRY OF THE ENVIRONMENT
(Displacement of Pumping Station attendants)


    5. Mr M.K.A. Jabbar asked the Minister for the Environment if he will explain why about sixty monthly-rated staff in his Ministry were recently converted to daily-rated staff resulting in a loss to them in take-home pay.

Column: 1019



     Mr Ong Pang Boon: Mr Speaker, Sir, in line with our national policy of upgrading operations and reducing manpower, the Ministry has progressively automated its sewage pumping stations. As a result, the 65 pumping station attendants have to be displaced. There are no vacancies of equivalent grade in the Ministry to absorb all the 65 attendants.

    Consequently, the pumping station attendants were informed in December 1980 that they would all be retired by the end of March 1981. At the same time, the Ministry circulated notices of monthly-rated job vacancies in the Ministry of the Environment, Ministry of Health, Prisons Department, Jurong Town Corporation, Housing and Development Board, Telecommunications Authority of Singapore and CISCO for the 65 pumping station attendants to apply. There were adequate monthly-rated posts to absorb the 65 attendants, if they were selected. The Ministry also circulated notices of vacancies in its skilled and semi-skilled daily-rated posts.

    To-date, 13 pumping station attendants have applied for the monthly-rated posts. Four were offered and accepted jobs with the Ministry with no break in service and no loss of salary, while two were selected and offered jobs by the Jurong Town Corporation. Thirty-nine chose to apply for the skilled and semi-skilled daily-rated posts in the Ministry, out of which 35 were offered appointments.

    It is inevitable that some of the pumping station attendants may suffer a drop in take-home pay, depending on the jobs they have applied for. However, several of the alternative jobs have higher wage ceilings. This means that in a few years' time, they can earn more in their new jobs than if they were to stay in their existing posts.

    My Ministry is also looking into the retraining of some of the attendants if they can be re-employed by the Ministry. This will upgrade them for higher skilled and higher paid jobs in the Ministry.

EXPRESSWAY TRAFFIC RULES, TOOTING OFFENCES
AND IMPATIENT DRIVERS


    6. Mr Eugene Yap Giau Cheng asked the Minister for Home Affairs (a) what steps his Ministry plans to take on "L" drivers and illegal parking along expressways to improve safety and traffic flow along those roadways: (b) what kind of scenario the Ministry expects to see along expressways when heavy and light goods vehicles are fitted with anti-speed devices from 1st August, 1981; (c) how many people have been warned or fined for indiscriminate use of vehicle horns and who are they mainly; and (d) whether the Traffic Police will ensure that impatient drivers at "give way" junctions are duly punished as they can be the cause of drivers in front of them not giving way at such junctions.

     The Minister for Home Affairs (Mr Chua Sian Chin): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Traffic Police has been taking enforcement action against illegal parking along expressways, and it will continue to do so. In the meantime, the PWD and the Traffic Police are in the process of drafting the Expressway Traffic Rules, 1981, to regulate traffic on the expressways.

    Besides prohibiting parking, the proposed Rules will prohibit vehicles from stopping or remaining at rest on the carriageway, except in the case of a breakdown. "L" drivers and riders will also be prohibited from driving along expressways.

    The promulgation of the Rules will enhance road safety and facilitate the smooth flow of traffic along the expressways.

    Heavy and light goods vehicles have speed limits up to the maximum of 50 km per hour, depending on the type of vehicle they belong to. When they travel on expressways, they must keep to their speed limits instead of the speed limit of 70 km per hour for the expressways. These vehicles will also have to keep to the left lane to prevent hindrance to other fast-moving vehicles on the expressways. Traffic Police will take enforcement

Column: 1021

action against those vehicles hindering the traffic flow or speeding in excess of their vehicle speed limits. Anti-speed devices will, therefore, facilitate enforcement action.

    The Traffic Police and the ROV Enforcement Unit have been taking enforcement action against drivers who indiscriminately use vehicle horns. Since 1976, an average of 79 drivers have been booked every year for committing this offence. The breakdown is: 
      Year                No. of Cases
      1976                     84
      1977                     70
      1978                     97
      1979                     71
      1980                     72


    Besides enforcing the Rules against indiscriminate tooting, ROV has also advised school bus operators to be more considerate and not to cause a nuisance by tooting unnecessarily, especially in housing estates in the early hours of the day.

    The Traffic Police's computerised records do not include the offence of indiscriminate use of vehicle horns. Therefore, I am unable to indicate what categories of offenders have been warned or fined for this offence.

    Action against impatient drivers can be taken only when they are found to have sounded their vehicle horns unnecessarily at give way junctions to force the drivers in front of them to move off without giving way to other vehicles. Otherwise, no action can be taken against them for displaying their impatience. All motorists are advised for their own safety as well as the safety of other road users to exercise patience when driving on the road. The Traffic Police is now concentrating their enforcement on those who do not give way when they should be at street junctions.

     Mr Eugene Yap Giau Cheng: Mr Speaker, Sir, will the Traffic Police intensify their action against illegal parking along expressways?

     Mr Chua Sian Chin: The answer is "Yes".

Column: 1022

THAIPUSAM KAVADI PROCESSION
(Ban on music)


    7. Mr M.K.A. Jabbar asked the Minister for Home Affairs whether the playing of any musical instrument, including the traditional drum, while devotees were carrying kavadis at this year's Thaipusam festival, was not allowed, and whether the Hindu Advisory Board had been consulted on this.

     Mr Chua Sian Chin: Mr Speaker, Sir, music was not permitted in this year's Thaipusam kavadi procession as in the past eight years. The ban on music along the route was introduced since 1973. The ban is not confined to the Thaipusam kavadi procession. It applies equally to all other religious processions. I wish to add that since 1973 religious foot processions, with the exception of Thaipusam, have not been allowed on our public roads and only religious processions on vehicles have been permitted. The exception has been made for Thaipusam because the devotees have to carry the kavadi and walk in fulfilment of their individual vows. The walk is allowed because it is a religious rite.

    In the years prior to 1973, music en route was permitted for the kavadi procession. However, the Police observed that with the accompaniment of music, the pace of the procession was slowed down. Further, the supporters, relatives and friends accompanying the devotees tended to dance to the beat of the music and occupied too large a portion of the road. The music also attracted large crowds of spectators. The result of this was that traffic flow was completely disrupted, creating huge traffic congestions in the city. Hence, the ban was imposed in 1973.

    The Police permit for the 1981 Thaipusam procession stipulated as in the past eight years, inter alia, that no music was to be played en route. On 12th January 1981 the Secretary of the Hindu Endowments Board, Mr S. Suppiah, wrote to the Ministry of Social Affairs appealing against the ban on music en route. The Ministry of Social Affairs

Column: 1023

sought the views of the Police who replied that the ban could not be lifted. They gave two reasons in rejecting the appeal of the Hindu Endowments Board. First, the ban applies not only to Hindu processions but also to processions of other religious groups. Secondly, Police experience prior to 1973 showed that music along the route of the kavadi procession aggravated traffic congestion.

Column: 1023

BUMBOATS
(Restrictions on passenger load)


    8. Mr Teo Chong Tee asked the Minister for Communications and Minister for Labour whether the Ministry of Communications will review the present regulation which restricts the number of passengers which may be carried by harbour craft plying between Changi Point and Pulau Tekong Besar and Pulau Ubin to 12 persons, as the operators are finding it increasingly difficult to keep their operation viable unless they are allowed to carry more passengers.

     The Minister for Communications and Minister for Labour (Mr Ong Teng Cheong): Mr Speaker, Sir, the present regulations do not restrict the number of passengers carried on bumboats between Changi Point and Pulau Tekong Besar and Pulau Ubin to 12 persons a boat. If the boat operator wishes to carry more than 12 persons, they can apply to the Marine Department. The boats must, however, be fitted with certain additional equipment to make it safe for the boats to carry the increased load. In addition, the boats will have to be inspected annually by surveyors from the Marine Department to ensure that they are kept in good condition.

    These requirements apply to all boats which carry more than 12 passengers and are necessary for the safety of passengers. If faithfully followed, it will help prevent the tragic loss of life that happens from time to time when an overloaded boat capsizes in the sea.

     Mr Teo Chong Tee (Changi): Sir, if the boat operators are allowed to carry more

Column: 1024

than 12 passengers in each boat, will it cost the boat operators extra money to apply for the licence to carry more passengers?

     Mr Ong Teng Cheong: Sir, if a bumboat carries more than 12 persons, it will be classified as a passenger boat. This will require a special licence and the boat operator has to pay the appropriate licence fee. But the Marine Department is prepared to review the licence fee if financial difficulties are faced by the bumboat operators.

Column: 1024

POLICY ON WORK PERMITS


    9. Mr M.K.A. Jabbar asked the Minister for Communications and Minister for Labour if he will state the Labour Ministry's policy on the issue of work permits.

     The Senior Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Labour (Mr Fong Sip Chee) (for the Minister for Communications and Minister for Labour): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Ministry's policy on work permits is to enable employers to import skilled, semiskilled and unskilled workers in support of our economic development. The policy has to ensure that the manpower needs of our industries are met and that any untoward social problems are not created.

    The Ministry currently implements seven work permit schemes. They are designed to cater for the different needs of each sector of our economy. The Work Permit Department has published guidelines on some of these schemes. I will ask the Department to send these publications to the Member for Radin Mas and other Members of this House for their information.

MAIN AND DEVELOPMENT ESTIMATES

YEAR 1ST APRIL, 1981 TO 31ST MARCH, 1982

     Mr Goh Chee Wee (Boon Lay): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head T be reduced by $10 in respect of Subhead TA-01 Project 8101 of the Development Estimates.

    Sir, as Singapore becomes more developed and our population becomes more affluent, let us not forget that a substantial number of our fellow citizens are still residing in the rural areas. They do not even have the chance to enjoy the basic facilities brought about by modern civilization, like street lighting and metalled roads.

    In this connection, I would like to comment that the provision of $3.96 million for kampong roads and $1 million for street lighting under the Urban and Rural Services programme for the whole of Singapore is grossly inadequate. Take Boon Lay Constituency, for instance. The allocation for the current financial year is a miserable $116,000. With rising cost and inflation, this miserable sum of money is sufficient only to repair and patch up some holes in existing roads. A large proportion of our rural population will have to continue to live in these substandard conditions for many years to come, if there is no change in our allocation policy.

    In requesting the Ministry of National Development to consider increasing the budget allocation under this vote, I hope the Minister will give this matter his serious and sympathetic consideration.

Column: 1026



     Mr Ho See Beng (Khe Bong): Sir, may I have your permission to speak now so that I do not have to move the next amendment standing in my name?

     The Chairman: All right.

     Mr Ho See Beng: Sir, before the introduction of parking coupons to replace the ticket system in the collection of parking fees, there was no surcharge collected if parking exceeds the time limit. The parking attendant would simply put a pink notice on the windscreen of the car to remind the motorist to pay another 40 cents as parking fees. But now things are different. If a motorist parks his car in excess of the time limit, he has to pay a surcharge of $2. Sir, why cannot the Car Parks Division, which is under the Urban and Redevelopment Authority, continue its former practice of charging another 40 cents if parking exceeds the time limit? The coupon system benefits the Department but creates a lot of inconvenience for the motoring public.

    In view of the impracticality of the coupon parking system, coupled with the unfair surcharge, I would like to urge the Minister to consider waiving the surcharge if he insists on carrying on with the coupon system.

     The Minister for National Development (Mr Teh Cheang Wan): Sir, the allocation of funds under URSC for each constituency is based on the location and the population in the constituency. Constituencies which have bigger projects or require more funds can make use of the savings available from other constituencies which do not make full use of their allocation. The URSC has monitored this procedure and found it to work satisfactorily.

    Funds so far allocated to the URSC programme have been adequate for projects, which are required by each Citizens' Consultative Committee, to be carried out in stages. The budget rose from $3.98 million in the financial year 1976 to $5.3 million in the

Column: 1027

financial year 1980. This will rise again to $5.63 million in the financial year 1981 to meet the demand for more services. I would like to assure the Member for Boon Lay that. additional funds can be made available if it is required.

    On the point raised by the hon. Member for Khe Bong, as I have told the House repeatedly last week, a grace period of five minutes for over-parking is given. In fact, this grace-period is often stretched to 10 or 15 minutes. The motorist should display sufficient coupons if he wishes to park for a longer period.

    A surcharge for over-parking is necessary as a deterrent to prevent abuse by motorists. If no surcharge is imposed, motorists will invariably display only the minimum number of coupons, and hope to get away with it. And they will not be unduly worried about parking over-time because if they are caught, they would not have to pay any surcharge. This is undesirable because more manpower will be required to check the coupons, to compute the additional fee and to collect the additional parking charges. It defeats the main purpose of the coupon parking system, i.e. to save manpower.

     Mr Ho See Beng: Why is the Minister worried about whether the motorists are worried or not so long as the URA get their parking fee of 40 cents or 80 cents or whatever the charge is. Payment of the fees due is the important thing, as far as the URA is concerned. If the motorist parks his car beyond the grace period of 15 minutes, the car park attendant is there to place a pink notice to remind the motorist to pay the fees. Whatever it is, the URA is not losing any revenue. So why does the Minister want to create worries for the motorist?

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Sir, the purpose of the coupon system is to save manpower. With the coupon system, the URA is able to reduce its manpower from 1,000 car park attendants to about 200 or 300 car park attendants. Therefore, there is a manpower saving of about 70%. If we have to station car park attendants in every car park to issue the pink ticket, then we will have to go back to

Column: 1028

the old system of engaging those staff which we have saved with the implementation of the coupon system. The Member for Khe Bong is, in fact, advocating that we go back to the old system, which means that the URA will have to engage the same number of car park attendants. I would be very happy indeed if the Member for Khe Bong can come out with a system whereby we can save manpower and also at the same time satisfy the motorists.

     Mr Ho See Beng: I have no doubts that the Minister will be very happy because he has saved up to about 70% expenditure on manpower. In the nature of things, Sir, if somebody gains, somebody else must lose. Otherwise how can the Minister save the money? He is saving money at the expense of the motoring public, which I think is not fair.

    Why cannot we go back to the old system? In this coupon system, we are still using a car park attendant to inspect whether the motorist has displayed the coupon or not. We can still carry on with the coupon system. Should the car park attendant see that the motorist has parked beyond the time limit, he just puts a notice to remind him to pay another 40 cents. Why cannot that be done?

     Mr Eugene Yap Giau Cheng: Sir, can I just join in to support my colleague?

     The Chairman: Yes.

     Mr Eugene Yap Giau Cheng: I see the problem like this. If an electric wire is to carry a high consumption load or very high voltage, the insulation is thicker and greater. Therefore, I presume the Minister most probably cannot feel what the ground reaction is like. Perhaps my colleague can.

    I think we can actually go back to the pink slip system. With all our computers and so on, we can trace back to recalcitrants, those people who habitually park for more than five or 10 minutes. Once the attendant places a pink slip on, he already has a record that this motorist has committed an offence once, and he can always trace back when necessary. And the fact that the motorist has to go to town to pay that parking fee is an inconveni-

Column: 1029

ence and, therefore, it is a deterrent by itself. I would like to support my colleague in this case.

     Mr Rohan bin Kamis (Telok Blangah): Sir, last year I suggested to the Minister to install a slot machine system so that the motorist can walk up to it, put in his coins in exchange for the correct number of labels with an adhesive back, and stick them on to his wind-screen. I understand that system has been tried. Would the Minister inform the House the finding on that system which I think is far superior to this coupon parking system that just shifts the burden from the car park attendant to the motorist.

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Sir, to answer the Member for Telok Blangah, I think the experiment has not been successful. What it amounts to is asking the motorist to walk up to the slot machine and get the ticket from the slot machine. This is equivalent to buying a coupon.
